FIGREF0.text: 2020 by The Society of Thoracic SurgeonsThoracic Surgical Oncology in Lombardy: How to Do It During COVID-19 Time?To the Editor:The health emergency from CoronaVIrus Disease-19 (COVID-19) requires special attention to lung cancer (LC) patients, vulnerable by tumour disease or the effects of oncological and radiotherapy treatments. Delayed LC surgeries could cause LC progressions with no longer resectable tumours.In stage I LC, a time-to-treat >8 weeks has associated with a reduction in 5-year survival; in stage III LC, a lag between neoadjuvant therapy and surgery >3 months was associated with shorter median survival (1, 2).On March 2020, to avoid the complete stop of oncological surgical procedures, Lombardy designed a hub system diverting all cancer patients to our Comprehensive Cancer Centre. Until 10 April 2020, in our Institute, all patients received an extensive COVID-19 related history interview, but the swab test was done only in symptomatic patients. Nonetheless, this approach has resulted in a biased selection.Despite the current lack of robust data (3), our Thoracic Surgery Division (first as volume and delivered quality in Italy) decided on testing for a baseline COVID-19 swab all LC surgical patients. The aim was to maintain, during COVID-19 epidemic, high-volume LC surgeries with wellestablished protected protocols and pathways.From 10 April 2020 up to now, even after a negative triage with temperature and medical history, the days before hospital admission, 58 entirely asymptomatic patients (scheduled for EBUS or LC surgery) underwent COVID-19 swabs. Of these, 7 (12.1%) patients had a positive COVID-19 -2 -swab and were rescheduled for surgery.In conclusion, our initial clinical evidence supports the mandatory use of the COVID-19 swabs as a screening tool in all asymptomatic patients who should undergo LC surgeries. The COVID-19 grid search in LC patients could decrease the in-hospital transmission (e.g. indirect transmission between patients using the same bathroom with standard disinfection). Besides, the early identification of asymptomatic COVID-19 patients could also avoid severe postoperative respiratory complications COVID-19 related and could protect the health-workers,
